title: Ollie Robinson on his rise at Kent, England star Sam Billings and Darren Stevens
text:
Wicketkeeper-batsman Ollie Robinson enjoyed a breakthrough season for Kent (Picture: Getty)

On the Kent County Cricket Club website, each first-team player has a profile page in which they reveal, amongst other things, their proudest moment in the sport.

It a measure of Ollie Robinson’s rise at Kent that his answer from last year – a first half-century for the county’s U11 team – is now amusingly obsolete.

‘Yeah, I should probably get them to change that! There’s been a few better moments since then,’ he says.

It’s been a surprising and special 18 months for wicketkeeper-batsman Robinson, who this summer established himself as a key player for Kent in all formats and a genuine asset with both the bat and gloves.

Robinson discussed his career and playing with Kent stars Sam Billings and Darren Stevens (Picture: Getty)

After signing his first professional contract in September 2017, Robinson had to wait almost a year before making his first-class debut. Playing as a specialist batsman at No. 7, the then-teenager scored 26 in his only innings as Kent smashed Leicestershire to boost their promotion hopes.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Robinson played two more red-ball matches that summer but few could have foreseen his development over the last six months.

Impressing in all formats, he finished the 2019 season with over 1,000 runs – 786 of which came in Division One of the County Championship – and 71 dismissals behind the stumps.

‘From a personal point of view, I was chuffed with how the season went,’ the 20-year-old says. ‘I didn’t expect it.

‘I didn’t expect to play any white-ball cricket at all really so that was obviously a huge bonus. Overall I’m just pleased with how the summer went. I’ve got to try and replicate that next year and keep on improving.’

And how does he plan to achieve that?

The Sidcup-born star finished the season with 71 dismissals (Picture: Getty)

‘If I look back at the season honestly, I think I need to be a little bit more consistent. I want to be more consistent. If you look at my scores, they tended to be either 100, 80 or not a lot.

‘If you can turn those 10s and 20s into 30s and 40s, then everything else moves up and you can go about scoring 1,000 runs in the season.

‘That’s something Zak [Crawley] has done really well this year. He got a lot of 30s and 40s that might not have be the prettiest but were still decent scores for the team. I’m not setting any specific goals at this stage – I didn’t really set a goal for this season – but I want to improve.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

The two highlights of Robinson’s summer – from a personal perspective, at least – were undoubtedly his brace of first-class centuries.

The first – a fluent, match-defining 143 against Warwickshire – came in April. A little over a month later, he made 103 against a Yorkshire attack that included former South Africa bowler Duanne Olivier, ex-England star Tim Bresnan and county legend Steven Patterson.

🤲 GRAB | Great low catch from @OllieRobinson7 to help dismiss Fisher!@harrypod23 gets the wicket and Yorkshire are eight down LIVE MATCH CENTRE ➡️ https://t.co/25sPGZr6eP #SuperKent pic.twitter.com/kjqqyW1ibP — Kent Cricket (@KentCricket) September 19, 2019

‘Scoring my first first-class hundred was special, it was a great day,’ Robinson says. ‘I wasn’t really spoken about before the season, so to justify my selection and to prove a few people wrong was nice.

‘I think the Yorkshire hundred was the better one. If you look at the attack and the way I played, it was completely different than the Warwickshire game. It was a battle. It was a lively pitch but I managed to scrap my way to a hundred.’

It is easy to see why Robinson did not expect to feature regularly for Kent this season. In Sam Billings, the county already possessed a superb wicketkeeper-batsman who had represented his country and featured in the Indian Premier League.

But Billings dislocated his shoulder at the start of the season and that presented Robinson with an opportunity. He took it with both hands and his rise was such that, when Billings returned later in the summer, it was to play alongside Robinson rather than to replace him.

Advertisement

In Billings, Robinson not only has a hugely talented team-mate and captain, but a perfect role model.

In Billings, Robinson has an ideal role model (Picture: Getty)

‘You try and learn things off everyone in the team but even more so off someone like Sam who has done a similar job to me and been very successful,’ Robinson adds.

‘I’ve spent a lot of time with Sam this year and we’ve had quite a few conversations about the game. He’s a good role model for sure.’

Billings, who last played for England in March, will surely add to his 36 caps this winter after being selected in the T20 squad for the tour to New Zealand.

‘I’m sure that’s his goal,’ Robinson says. ‘Sam is a great player so I’m sure he can get back in the England team now he’s fit. Everyone knows how good he is, and he showed it with three hundreds in a row at the end of the season.’

Robinson also speaks highly of another Kent team-mate, one who made his first-class debut before he was even born.

Robinson is glad to see Stevens extend his stay at Kent (Picture: Getty)

Darren Stevens, 43, has scored over 26,000 runs and taken almost 800 wickets in a remarkable county career that began in 1997. He looked set to leave Kent at the end of the season but earned a contract extension after a brilliant finish to the summer.

‘Playing with Darren is great,’ says Robinson. ‘Everyone looks up to him. He’s just a great guy to have around and obviously a legend at Kent. We get on well, he’s a funny guy. He’s an incredible player, too.’

Advertisement

It was Stevens’ heroics at Headingley last month that finally convinced Kent to offer him a new deal.

The all-rounder obliterated Yorkshire with a brutal double century, before taking seven wickets in an emphatic win which helped Division One new-boys Kent finish fourth in the top-flight of the County Championship.

Robinson recalls: ‘That was one of the most ridiculous things I’ve ever seen. He was pretty tired when he got to about 140, so from then on it was just an absolute onslaught.

‘I think everyone was thinking after that game, “surely he will sign a new deal now” and he did which is great because he’s still a top player.’

Robinson was Kent’s third leading run-scorer in all competitions (Picture: Getty)

After discussing county cricket veteran Stevens, the conversation returns to Robinson’s fledgling career.

‘I always wanted to become a professional cricketer,’ he says. ‘And I always believed I could… but it was just that little bit extra that you have to give to get there.

‘The first time I realised I might make it was when I got picked for a pre-season trip to West Indies. I was obviously around the squad a lot and I remember thinking, “I’ve got a chance here…”

‘It’s gone pretty well since then.’

Ollie Robinson has certainly come a long way since scoring fifties for Kent U11s.
